Option C. TRAM Flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The TRAM flap is a reconstructive technique that uses tissue from the lower abdominal wall, including the rectus abdominis muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is often employed in breast reconstruction, providing a large amount of tissue.
  • There are two types: pedicled TRAM flap (retains its blood supply through the rectus muscle) and free TRAM flap (microvascular reconstruction).

 

Option D. VRAM Flap (Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The VRAM flap is similar to the TRAM flap but uses tissue from the vertical orientation of the rectus abdominis muscle.

 

  • It is also used in breast reconstruction and abdominal wall reconstruction.
  • Like the TRAM flap, it can be pedicled or free, depending on the surgical technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flap surgery is a type of plastic surgery that uses tissues from another part of the body to close open wounds while having its own blood supply.
  • The site from which the tissue is obtained is called the donor site, while the site where the tissue is transferred is called the recipient site. Flaps may be of soft tissue, skin, muscle, bone, fat or fascia.

questions.text: Before conducting an A-V fistula procedure, which of the following tests is typically conducted? The image of the test is given below: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allen's test

 

The given image represents Allen’s test, which indicates the patency of the radial and ulna artery in supplying the hand. Both arteries are compressed alternatively, to check if limb will survive in absence of radial artery (which will be now used in creation of AV fistula).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson's test: Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Patient is asked to turn his head to affected side and take a deep breath. Ipsilateral radial pulse will become weak in thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Elevated arm stress test: Elevated arm stress test is a diagnostic tool used in the identification of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome. The patient is asked to abduct his shoulder and flex his forearm and open and close his fists. In presence of thoracic outlet syndrome, the affected limb will get cramps (ischemic) or paresthesia (neurogenic).

 

 

Option D. Nicoladoni's test: Nicoladoni's test is to be elicited in cases of AV fistula. There is slowing of heart rate in response to manual compression of fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the X-Ray image shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jejunal atresia

 

The X-ray image provided shows a characteristic feature known as the "triple bubble" appearance, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. In the context of pediatric radiology, this appearance is caused by the presence of three dilated gas-filled bowel loops proximal to the atretic segment of the jejunum. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an obstruction in the jejunum, leading to this distinctive radiological sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: This condition typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on an X-ray, not a triple bubble. The double bubble sign shows two dilated areas—one in the stomach and one in the duodenum—due to an obstruction in the duodenum.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. The X-ray sign is free air under the diaphragm, which is not seen in the given image.

 

Option D. Hirschsprung’s disease: This is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to obstruction. The radiographic features might include a distended colon with a transition zone, but it does not present with the triple bubble appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological findings:

 

  • Jejunal atresia or ileal atresia: Triple Bubble Appearance
  • Duodenal atresia: Double Bubble sign
  • Infantile pyloric stenosis: Single Bubble sign

choices.text: Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor.
Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein.

questions.text: The following criteria must be met to perform a Whipple procedure except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

The Whipple procedure, or pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a surgical technique used to treat pancreatic cancer, especially tumors located in the head of the pancreas. Unlike many other cancers, a histologic (pathologic) confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor is not required before proceeding with a radical resection. This is due to the high rate of false-negative biopsies and the high sensitivity and specificity of imaging findings for pancreatic cancer. The critical criteria for determining resectability and proceeding with the Whipple procedure include the absence of distant metastasis (e.g., liver metastasis), the absence of aortic encasement, and the absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of aortic encasement: Correct. Aortic encasement indicates unresectability.

 

Option C. Absence of liver metastasis: Correct. Liver metastasis indicates unresectability.

 

Option D. Absence of gross invasion of the superior mesenteric vessels and portal vein: Correct. Gross invasion indicates unresectability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pathologic confirmation of the pancreatic head tumor is not required before performing a Whipple procedure, due to the high accuracy of imaging studies and the potential for false-negative biopsies.

questions.text: A malignant melanoma descending into the reticular dermis, but not invading the subcutaneous tissue, would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clark's level IV

 

Explanation:

 

Clark's levels are used to describe the depth of invasion of melanoma into the skin. They are part of the prognostic staging for malignant melanoma, indicating how far the tumor has penetrated vertically:

 

  • Clark's level I: Confined to the epidermis (in situ melanoma).
  • Clark's level II: Invasion into the papillary dermis but does not fill it.
  • Clark's level III: Fills the papillary dermis and impinges on the reticular dermis but does not invade it.
  • Clark's level IV: Invades the reticular dermis.
  • Clark's level V: Invades the subcutaneous tissue.

 

A melanoma that descends into the reticular dermis but does not invade the subcutaneous tissue is classified as Clark's level IV. This classification is crucial for determining prognosis and treatment strategies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clark's level I: Confined to the epidermis, not appropriate for this case.

 

Option B. Clark's level III: Fills the papillary dermis and touches but does not invade the reticular dermis.

 

Option D. Clark's level V: Involves invasion into the subcutaneous tissue, which is beyond the reticular dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A melanoma invading the reticular dermis but not the subcutaneous tissue is classified as Clark's level IV.

questions.text: Ileitis Backwash is seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulcerative Colitis

 

Explanation:

 

Backwash Ileitis refers to the involvement of the terminal ileum in Ulcerative Colitis (UC). This phenomenon occurs when inflammation from the colon extends into the terminal ileum, often due to the reflux of colonic contents through an incompetent ileocecal valve. This condition is typically observed in cases of extensive colitis and is characterized by mucosal inflammation limited to a few centimeters proximal to the ileocecal valve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crohn’s Disease: This condition involves transmural inflammation of any part of the gastrointestinal tract, often including extensive ileal involvement, but it is not termed Backwash Ileitis.

 

Option C. Colonic Carcinoma: This does not cause backwash ileitis.

 

Option D. Ileal Polyp: This is a localized growth in the ileum and is not related to backwash ileitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backwash Ileitis is the involvement of the terminal ileum seen in Ulcerative Colitis.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

To summarize, each of the mentioned criteria - size, symptomatic presentation, and rapid growth - are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms. Thus, the answer is: D. All of the above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size more than 5.5 cm in males:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is greater than 5.5 cm in diameter has an increased risk of rupture. The risk of rupture and complications rises significantly as the size of the aneurysm increases. For this reason, surgical intervention is typically recommended when an AAA reaches this size in males.

 

Option B. Patient is experiencing abdominal pain: Abdominal pain can be a sign that the aneurysm is expanding or is about to rupture. If a patient presents with abdominal pain and an AAA, it's often treated as a surgical emergency. The pain might be caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures or due to impending rupture.

 

Option C. Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA is another indicator of increased rupture risk. An expansion of more than 0.5 cm in 6 months indicates that the aneurysm is growing quickly. Rapid growth can be a sign of structural changes in the aneurysm wall that increase the risk of rupture. Therefore, even if the AAA is smaller than the usual 5.5 cm threshold, if it's growing quickly, surgical intervention is typically considered.

 

Educational Objective:


Abdominal aortic aneurysms require surgical intervention if the size exceeds 5.5 cm in males, the patient presents with abdominal pain, or if there is an expansion of more than 0.5 cm within 6 months.

choices.text: 10-year-old child with multi organ dysfunction syndrome
49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence
74-year-old woman with end stage renal disease

questions.text: In the case of a 37-year-old woman who has been declared brain dead and whose family has agreed to donate her organs, who would be the most suitable or optimal candidate to receive the organs? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31-year-old women with renal failure

 

This candidate is closer in age to the donor, and if her medical condition and compatibility allow for a successful kidney transplant, she may be the most suitable recipient for the kidney.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A 10-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome: This candidate is likely in urgent need of multiple organ transplantation, and a younger recipient may generally have better long-term outcomes. However, etiology of multi-organ dysfunction is not provided, thereby the long term prognosis of the patient is uncertain.

 

Option B. A 49-year-old alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence: While this candidate may benefit from a liver transplant, alcoholism can pose challenges to transplantation success. The one-month abstinence period is relatively short, and further evaluation of his liver condition and suitability for transplantation would be necessary.

 

Option C. A 74-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease: Given the age of the recipient and the fact that she has end-stage renal disease, a kidney transplant from the 37-year-old donor may not provide the best long-term outcomes. Older recipients may have a lower life expectancy, and the benefit of a kidney transplant may be less significant compared to younger recipients.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

questions.text: What should be the treatment in a patient who presented in the emergency with respiratory distress, dilated neck veins and an Xray chest showing large amount of air on the left side along with mediastinal shift as shown? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

 

The chest X-ray findings in this patient indicate a tension pneumothorax. The hallmarks on the X-ray include a large amount of air on the left side, a depressed diaphragm, an ipsilateral collapsed lung, a shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and the absence of bronchovascular markings on the affected side. These signs, combined with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory distress and dilated neck veins, confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management of tension pneumothorax involves immediate decompression to relieve the pressure. This is achieved by inserting a wide bore needle into the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line in children, or in the 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary line in adults. This procedure allows the trapped air to escape, relieving the pressure on the lung and the mediastinum, thereby stabilizing the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation is utilized in severe respiratory distress cases, it does not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax. The primary intervention required is immediate decompression.

 

Option C. Open thoracotomy: Open thoracotomy is a surgical procedure used for various thoracic conditions, including cardiac tamponade, but it is not the first-line treatment for tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle decompression is necessary for tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Pericardiocentesis: Pericardiocentesis involves the removal of fluid from the pericardial sac and is indicated for cardiac tamponade. It is not an appropriate treatment for tension pneumothorax, which requires decompression of the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In the case of a tension pneumothorax, immediate decompression with a wide bore needle in the appropriate intercostal space is essential to relieve pressure and stabilize the patient.

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes surgery for a clean-contaminated wound after receiving prophylactic antibiotics. What is the expected rate of surgical site infection in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3%

 

After the administration of prophylactic antibiotics, the anticipated rate of surgical site infection in a patient with a clean contaminated wound is 3%.

 

This is a reasonable estimate for the expected rate of SSI in clean-contaminated surgical wounds. These wounds have a controlled level of contamination, and prophylactic antibiotics are given to reduce the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-2%: This range represents a lower infection rate, which is more commonly associated with surgeries in clean wounds.

 

Option C. 13-20%: This range is much higher and is more typical for surgeries in contaminated or dirty wounds, where the risk of infection is significantly elevated.

 

Option D. 20-30%: This range represents a very high infection rate and is more characteristic of surgeries performed in dirty or heavily contaminated wounds. It would be unusual to expect such a high infection rate in a clean-contaminated surgical case with prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A surgical site infection (SSI) is an infection that occurs at or near a surgical incision or operative site after surgery. SSIs can range from mild to severe and can affect the skin and underlying tissues, including muscles and organs. These infections are a common complication of surgery and can lead to various health problems if not treated promptly.

 

Key characteristics and considerations related to surgical site infections (SSIs) include:

 

  1. Classification:
    • SSIs are classified into three main categories based on the timing of onset:
    • Superficial Incisional SSI: Infection occurs within 30 days after the operation and involves only the skin and subcutaneous tissues at the incision site.
    • Deep Incisional SSI: Infection also occurs within 30 days after the operation but involves deeper tissues, such as muscles and fascia, at the incision site.
    • Organ/Space SSI: Infection can occur within 30 or 90 days after the operation and affects any part of the body other than the incision area. This can include infections within the abdominal or chest cavities.
       
  2. Signs and Symptoms:
    • The symptoms of an SSI may include redness, warmth, swelling, pain, and discharge at or near the surgical site.
    • Systemic symptoms like fever, chills, and malaise can also occur if the infection is severe or has spread.
       
  3. Prevention:
    • Preventive measures are crucial in reducing the risk of SSIs. These measures include:
      • Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis
      • Proper hand hygiene and sterile techniques during surgery
      • Maintaining a clean surgical environment
      • Adequate skin preparation before incision
      • Proper wound care and postoperative monitoring
         
  4. Treatment:
    • Treatment of an SSI typically involves antibiotics to target the specific bacteria causing the infection.
    • In some cases, additional interventions may be necessary, such as wound drainage, debridement (removal of infected tissue), or, rarely, reoperation.
       
  5. Complications:
    • If left untreated or not managed appropriately, SSIs can lead to more serious complications, such as abscess formation, cellulitis, tissue necrosis, and the spread of infection to other parts of the body.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck Stabilization
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X ray
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support
The doctor should order a cervical X ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident presented with paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization

 

The given clinical situation is suggestive of a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

 

This option is correct because the patient is experiencing paralysis of both upper and lower limbs, which is indicative of a potential cervical spine injury. In such cases, it is crucial not to move the patient until the cervical spine is stabilized to prevent any further damage. Using a portable X-ray machine can help assess the cervical spine without the need to move the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-rays: The patient's cervical spine must be stabilized before any radiographic evaluation is performed.

 

Option C. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral views without any cervical support: This option is not advisable because taking X-rays without cervical support can potentially worsen the patient's condition if there is a cervical spine injury. The patient's neck should be stabilized before any imaging is done.

 

Option D. The doctor should order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself: This option is not recommended because moving the patient without proper cervical spine stabilization can lead to further injury. The priority should be to immobilize the cervical spine and use imaging techniques that do not require moving the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management in a trauma patient with suspected cervical fracture consists of:

 

  1. The immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases is spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board
  2. It is followed by eliciting extremity movement to grossly assess spinal cord function. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicated an associated fracture.

 

Imaging is done by X-ray or CT with portable X-ray machines being preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but they cannot be used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction.

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about intestinal transplantation: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts

 

This statement is incorrect. While multi-visceral transplantation, which includes the intestine along with other abdominal organs like the liver and pancreas, can occur, it is not the most common type of intestinal transplantation. Isolated intestinal transplantation, where only the intestine is transplanted, is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions: This statement is correct. Intestinal transplantation is not as widely performed as other organ transplants like kidney or liver transplantation because the intestine is known to trigger vigorous rejection reactions.

 

Option C. The most dangerous complication is sepsis: This statement is correct. Sepsis is indeed a significant and life-threatening complication associated with intestinal transplantation. The immunosuppressive medications used to prevent rejection can increase the risk of infections, including sepsis.

 

Option D. The most common indication is ischemia. (Correct): Ischemia is one of the common indications for intestinal transplantation. It is often used when patients have suffered from ischemic bowel disease and other treatments have been ineffective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multi-visceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

 

All the other statements are correct.

 

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option when the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

 

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic as it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56-75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.
